author: {'steamid': '76561197996892993', 'num_games_owned': 6130, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1492706466}
review:
Blackwood Crossing ist eine wunderschÃ¶ne und sehr emotionale Reise. Wer sich hier auf die Story und das Geschehen einlassen kann, wird hier seine Freude mit haben. 

Zugegeben, anfangs dauert es ein bisschen, bis die Story in Fahrt kommt. Oft werden einem nur SÃ¤tze an den Kopf geschmissen, die erst im Verlauf der weiteren Geschichte dann Sinn ergeben. Im weiteren Verlauf stolpert man immer wieder Ã¼ber kleine RÃ¤tsel, die nicht sonderlich schwer sind, aber trotzdem ganz nett gemacht sind. Diese tragen auch maÃŸgeblich zur Story bei - ehe man sie nicht gelÃ¶st hat, gehts auch nicht weiter in dem Abschnitt.
Ich hatte in dem Spiel ganz oft "Wow" Momente, da plÃ¶tzlich Dinge passiert sind in der Umgebung sowie Story technisch, mit denen ich Ã¼berhaupt nicht gerechnet hatte. 

An der Steuerung sowie an der Grafik hab ich persÃ¶nlich nichts zu meckern, auch der Sound ist im Spiel immer sehr passend und atmosphÃ¤risch. Den Preis fÃ¼r 16 Euro finde ich angemessen, einige werden zwar meckern, dann wenn man "schnell" unterwegs ist, wird man das Spiel sicherlich in gut ca. 3 Stunden durch haben. Ist aber in Anbetracht vom Gesamtbild doch zumutbar meiner Meinung nach. 

Ich kann dieses Spiel deswegen jedem empfehlen, der gerne Walking Simulatoren mit einer wunderschÃ¶nen Story spielen mag. Aber seid gewarnt: Legt euch lieber schon eine Packung TaschentÃ¼cher zur Seite. ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198037149412', 'num_games_owned': 488, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1494792320}
review: Ein sehr empotionales Abendteuer. Trotz der kurzen Spielzeit ist die tiefe der Geschichte atemraubend. Ich sage sowas selten aber hier gilt wirklich: Wer etwas fÃ¼r das Herz haben mÃ¶chte, sollte dieses Spiel auf jedenfall gespielt haben!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970995191', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1494770152}
review:
#blackwoodcrossing  
Bislang habe ich das Spiel lediglich anspielen kÃ¶nnen. Dennoch kann ich sagen das es mich irgendwie packt. Die Story ist strange aber interessant, eventuell auch genau deswegen. Die Spielebeschreibung sagt im Prinzip auch schon alles aus um es anspielen zu wollen, und ja... Ich werde es weiterhin spielen und bin gespannt was mich noch so erwartet. Wirklich super aufgebaut das ganze.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074123690', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1494626660}
review: I loved everything about this game. For me, it was very reminiscent of the game Papo & Yo. It had excellent story telling, you really felt connnected to the characters throughout the game, and it wsa overall just gorgeous. The small interactions you have with each of the minor characters really helps to set the tone and give a good background as to who these two siblings are. Yes it is a relatively short game, I finished it in one sitting, but I feel all the better for playing it. As with Papo & Yo, the story sticks with you and really makes a mark on how you perceive things and how others feel in situations. If you're looking for a game that is story heavy and pulls you into the world and makes you feel a part of it, this is for you. Otherwise you may or may not prefer this game. I'd say this game is worth it at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086151669', 'num_games_owned': 439, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1491671726}
review:
https://niveloculto.com/analisis-blackwood-crossing/

La bÃºsqueda del medio mÃ¡s adecuado para expresar una emociÃ³n personal es una de las tareas mÃ¡s complejas a las que se enfrenta un artista a lo largo de su vida. Como muchos otros, el Ã¡mbito del videojuego se ha ganado ya su puesto fijo como escenario para plasmar este tipo de sensaciones.

Junto a trabajos tan reseÃ±ables como The Beginnerâ€™s Guide o Dear Esther, Blackwood Crossing se presenta como una historia interactiva que sirve Ãºnica y exclusivamente a un fin: dialogar con el espectador sobre un concepto. Y es que la opera prima de los britÃ¡nicos Paper Seven se fundamenta en el intento de transmitir la complejidad emocional de la nostalgia y la pÃ©rdida. Pero esta lecciÃ³n no se desvela de primera mano, sino que se va manifestando poco a poco segÃºn avanzamos en la aventura.

De hecho, Blackwood Crossing se presenta de primeras como un caballo de Troya. Su inocente imagen no advierte sobre el duro mensaje que nos quiere transmitir.

Al comenzar la historia nos ponemos en la piel de Scarlett una joven inglesa que estÃ¡ realizando un viaje en tren con su hermano pequeÃ±o, Finn. En un momento dado nuestro hermanito se escapa y nos invita a perseguirle por los vagones. Es entonces cuando hacen acto de presencia diversos elementos onÃ­ricos, anticipando que nada es lo que parece a primera vista. Buen ejemplo de ello es que un conejo blanco nos invita a perseguirle, como si fuÃ©semos la pequeÃ±a Alicia de Lewis Carroll.

En este primer segmento del tÃ­tulo comenzamos a descubrir un mundo que habÃ­amos dejado atrÃ¡s por haber crecido. Nos devuelve a la mirada de un niÃ±o y observamos todo lo que la supuesta madurez nos ha arrebatado. La premisa es interesante desde luego. El problema es que, desde el punto de vista jugable, las mecÃ¡nicas introducidas son mÃ¡s bien un obstÃ¡culo que entorpece el transcurso de la historia mÃ¡s que ayudar a su desarrollo.

El gÃ©nero denominado como walking simulator ha demostrado ser un tanto polÃ©mico desde que comenzÃ³ a popularizarse. Muchos jugadores sienten que estÃ¡n viendo una pelÃ­cula mÃ¡s que participando en una historia, y demandan mÃ¡s acciones por parte del usuario. Pero a veces no entienden que esto no es necesario, y que el simple hecho de que los espectadores seamos los que controlemos al personaje por el escenario es suficiente para romper las barreras impuestas por el cine y otorgar a estos videojuegos un valor Ãºnico.

Sin embargo, por miedo a caer en esta supuesta monotonÃ­a o falta de interacciÃ³n, los chicos de PaperSeven han introducido una serie de puzles en la experiencia que al final resultan mÃ¡s bien tediosos y lastran la naturalidad de lo que se narra.

Concretamente en varios escenarios deberemos buscar â€œemparejarâ€ a dos personajes o recoger diversos objetos para que la historia avance. Sin duda acciones carentes de interÃ©s y que podrÃ­an haber sido omitidas sin ningÃºn problema.

Tampoco ayuda que el control se sienta bastante lento e impreciso. A este respecto es un poco indiferente si se utiliza mando o ratÃ³n, ya que ninguna de las dos experiencias es verdaderamente cÃ³moda.

Desde el punto de vista formal sin embargo las impresiones son mucho mejores. El juego apuesta por una estÃ©tica cartoon muy colorida, que recuerda a lo visto en el magnÃ­fico Life is Strange. AdemÃ¡s, el diseÃ±o de algunos personajes secundarios junto con el componente surrealista de los escenarios dotan a la aventura de una personalidad especial.

En definitiva, Blackwood Crossing cuenta con todos los elementos necesarios para convertirse en una gran historia interactiva: un argumento sÃ³lido y profundo, un apartado visual original y atractivo, una banda sonora acorde y una duraciÃ³n reducida.

El Ãºnico punto negativo es la implementaciÃ³n de alguna de sus mecÃ¡nicas jugables, y lo tosco que resulta en ocasiones su control. Pero por fortuna esto es perfectamente olvidable una vez que nos acostumbramos.

Por ello serÃ¡ sin duda un tÃ­tulo recomendable para los amantes del gÃ©nero, que encontrarÃ¡n en Ã©l una emotiva historia sobre lo difÃ­cil que es crecer y acerca del dolor de la pÃ©rdida.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961133543', 'num_games_owned': 1211, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1517552265}
review:
Really loved the Game! 

+ The Story is Short but i think the lenght of it fits the storyline perfect.
+ The Story and its telling! Really well done. The end was something special / emotional
+ Graphics look nice
+ nice Setting
+ loveable characters; Really good character design!

~ Puzzels are allright. Some are fairly easy, some need more thinking behind it
~ It isnt allways clear what to do next. Some hints may be nice from time to time 

- Well the only bad thing i noticed was, that you cant sprint. I like to sprint in games. Ok, you might want a player to explore the game and really take in the level and character design but you should atleast give the Player the option to choose for himself.

Well summed up it is a really really good game if you enjoy good character and level design and love an incredible Story to it. You will play through it fairly quick but youll enjoy every second of it.

Worth a buy: Defently. I loved it, payed full price (around 16 â‚¬ i think) and i am not dissapointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960514574', 'num_games_owned': 1956, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1494100746}
review:
DÃ©veloppÃ© par PaperSeven , Blackwood Crossing est un jeu d'aventure dans lequel on incarne Scarlett, une jeune femme qui se rÃ©veille en sursaut dans un train en compagnie de son petit frÃ¨re Finn. Sans trop comprendre ce qui lui arrive et dÃ©sorientÃ©e, elle va vite se rendre compte que quelque chose ne tourne pas rond dans ce train aprÃ¨s avoir rencontrÃ© un passager mystÃ©rieux et dotÃ© d'une tÃªte de lapin. S'ensuit ensuite une aventure unique qui nous amÃ¨nera plus loin dans la vie de Scarlett et de ce qui a pu arriver de dramatique dans sa vie.

Blackwood Crossing est donc un nouveau jeu surfant sur la vague des histoire intÃ©ractives dramatiques Ã  l'instar de What Remains of Edith Finch. On va donc explorer un univers complexe et mystÃ©rieux dans lequel les relations entre Finn et Scarlett sont l'axe central. Alors qu'ils sont orphelins, leur relation unique va connaitre un nouveau tournant avec l'adolescence et l'envie d'Ã©mancipation de Scarlett. Par le biais de scÃ¨nes originales et de quelques puzzles, on va dÃ©couvrir ce qui leur est arrivÃ© et quel est le terrible terminus de ce train.

Un tramway nommÃ© dÃ©prime.
Le jeu se joue Ã  la premiÃ¨re personne et l'on incarne uniquement Scarlett. Celle-ci peut donc se dÃ©placer, prendre des objets, les utiliser mais aussi utiliser la magie! Sorte de Alice in Wonderland dans la mise en scÃ¨ne et la narration, Blackwood Crossing Ã©vite tout de mÃªme la facilitÃ© grÃ¢ce la relation forte entre ses deux principaux protagonistes. On va devoir avancer dans le train et rÃ©soudre Ã  chaque fois de petites Ã©nigmes pour dÃ©couvrir petit Ã  petit l'inexorable final un brin prÃ©visible tout de mÃªme. N'espÃ©rez pas la complexitÃ© d'un point and click, il faudra juste retrouver le bon objet Ã  utiliser au bon endroit ou alors recrÃ©er des dialogues entre plusieurs personnages afin de dÃ©bloquer un mur invisible. Rien de bien complexe en fait et il ne vous faudra que 2-3 heures pour en voir le bout et dÃ©bloquer une majoritÃ© d'achievements.

La rÃ©alisation est plutÃ´t trÃ¨s bonne avec de beaux effets et quelques dÃ©cors splendides, on est pas spÃ©cialement bluffÃ© mais le rÃ©sultat est convaincant. Je n'ai pas pu jouÃ© au jeu avant car Ã©tant dotÃ© d'un Ã©cran 144Hz, je souffrais de gros soucis de fluiditÃ© et de stabilitÃ©. Heureusement, un patch salvateur est disponible depuis quelques jours et le jeu tourne comme un charme sur des configurations rÃ©centes. Sachez que le jeu est traduit en franÃ§ais dans le texte mais pas dans les doublages ce qui dommage car certaines discussions sont complexes Ã  apprÃ©hender et Ã  comprendre en fonction de son niveau d'anglais. je vous conseille fortement d'activer les sous-titres.

Les 2 font la paire.
Blackwood Crossing est plutÃ´t facile et il ne vous faudra que quelques minutes pour comprendre ce que le jeu attend de vous mis Ã  part quelques scÃ¨nes qui sont un brin mal expliquÃ©es. On aura plus de souci avec le maniement de Scarlett et Ã  cause de la trÃ¨s forte sensibilitÃ© de la souris ou de la manette qu'avec les puzzles et autres phases de rÃ©flexion. Au niveau gameplay, le jeu est assez limitÃ© et on se demandera Ã  plusieurs reprises Ã  quoi servent les objets que l'on ramasse si ce n'est pour dÃ©bloquer des achievements. La gestion de l'inventaire est assez bordÃ©lique Ã  la manette et il faudra quelques minutes pour s'y faire. Certains dÃ©placements ne sont pas facilitÃ© plus tard dans l'aventure avec une gestion des collisions parfois aux fraises et une lenteur chronique chez Scarlett.

Vous allez me dire, ton jeu, ca fleure bon le navet car je passe plus de temps Ã  Ã©numÃ©rer ses errances qu'Ã  parler de ses qualitÃ©s et vous aurez tord! En effet, Blackwood Crossing est un trÃ¨s beau jeu mais qui reste excessivement frustrant Ã  cause des petits dÃ©fauts dont je parle. Refaire plusieurs fois les dialogues entre 2 protagonistes qui changent de personnages en fonction de la scÃ¨ne n'a rien de fun ni d'immersif, c'est juste pÃ©nible. Faire 15 allers-retours pour espÃ©rer trouver la bonne paire est usant au bout d'un moment et pourtant on s'accroche. Oui car le jeu est vraiment remarquable a niveau de son histoire et ce qu'il dÃ©crit au niveau des Ã©tapes que doit franchir Scarlett pour accepter l'inÃ©vitable et oppressante vÃ©ritÃ©.

Les 5 Ã©tapes et au final, la dÃ©livrance.
Blackwood Crossing parvient magistralement Ã  retranscrire ce que peut ressentir Finn et Scarlett dans cette situation. Finn ne se souvient pas de ses parents, ca le hante et le ronge de l'intÃ©rieur. Ses dÃ©mons sont superbement reprÃ©sentÃ©s dans le jeu tout comme son appel au secours Ã  sa sÅ“ur. Scarlett, quand Ã  elle, va devoir grandir et remettre son cÅ“ur en ordre de marche pour aller secourir son frÃ¨re de sa propre prison sentimentale tout en essayant de se reconstruire, elle, avec toute l'aide qu'elle pourra trouver dans le reste de sa famille ou son petit ami. Le soin du dÃ©tail apportÃ© par les dÃ©veloppeurs est remarquable que ce soit au niveau des situations qu'au niveau des dÃ©cors et autres posters qui trainent ici et lÃ . Cet univers est cohÃ©rent et d'une mÃ©lancolie Ã  faire fondre les moins sentimentaux d'entre vous.

Le jeu est disponible sur PC, Xbox One et PS4 au prix de  15.99â‚¬ ce qui peut paraitre un brin cher devant le temps de jeu. Je vous conseille d'attendre des soldes Steam afin de vous le procurer pour moins cher. Blackwood Crossing reste un jeu Ã  part Ã©vite les piÃ¨ges du genre tout en essayant quelque chose de nouveau. Malheureusement pour lui, le frein ne vient pas de l'histoire mais bel et bien du jeu en lui-mÃªme ce qui est d'autant plus rageant. Oui le final est on ne peut plus prÃ©visible mais il est tellement bien amenÃ© qu'on pardonnera facilement PaperSeven d'avoir sorti les grosses ficelles et le cahier des charges lacrymal du bon drama. J'ai beaucoup apprÃ©ciÃ© le jeu mais trop de dÃ©fauts ont entachÃ© mon plaisir pour que je puisse vous le conseiller les yeux fermÃ©s.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970329288', 'num_games_owned': 2788, 'num_reviews': 1451, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1494021059}
review:
GTX 1060 Gameplay footage:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5TPwUa14b74

My Thoughts:
A sleek and stylish adventure with breathtaking artwork, instantly likeable characters, charming locations and an intriguing story. You can tell a lot of pride, hardwork, creativity and love has gone itno this title. (Watch my video above to see if it's a game for you)

Game Details:
Blackwood Crossing is a story-driven first-person adventure game. An intriguing and emotive tale exploring the fragile relationship between orphaned siblings, Scarlett and Finn. When their paths cross with a mysterious figure, an ordinary train ride evolves into a magical story of life, love and loss.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069184304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1492736243}
review:
I recommend this game, but only when it's on sale. Here's a short summary of why:

-The game is pretty short--so even if it's nice for the time you play it, unless you feel like you'll play it multiple times for accomplishments.

-There is minimal gameplay--if you just like story immersion over interactivity though, this won't be a problem for you.

-It's very pretty and very moving--but for a short while, so like I said, get it on sale.

My longer review is here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KvuRyZiUUUk

Thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198008070718', 'num_games_owned': 482, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1492789099}
review:
Blackwood Crossing has been on my radar for quite a while. Interestingly enough, I first heard about it on a medium irrelevant with gaming and related journalism. It had been in the back of my mind ever since and I knew little about the theme, its gameplay or its exact genre. What caught my gaze and sparked my interest in the first place when I saw those early screenshots, were the unique art style and the excellent character models, surrounded by a magical and dream-like world.

The game is the lovechild of the newly established (2011) Indie Studio, Paper Seven, some of its members being old Black Rock Studio employees (Split/Second , Pure). Itâ€™s the first actual game that they make, that meets their own goal of creating titles with absolute love for their work and the industry in general. That love is apparent in the game visuals, be it assets, or character models and animations, professing a great deal of hard work, on the same level with many animation studios of far greater budgets.

The story is about Scarlett ÎºÎ±Î¹ Finn, two orphaned siblings and their train ride, which evolves to be a ride on their memories, thought-train and the issues of their relationship. I canâ€™t reveal more without ruining the very point of telling a well written and tender story, filled with feelings common to all of us, which is bound to wake emotions, especially to those with much younger/older siblings. After a certain point the story gets predictable, but performances are stellar-especially Finnâ€™s. 

What fails the game, story-wise, is that on top of being too short already (about 3 hours) what remains is not enough to develop the issues that are raised. In addition to further developing Scarlett/Finnâ€™s relationship, which is essential to create a greater emotional investment to them.

There are some issues regarding the port to the PC platform, naturally locked at 30 fps featuring some non-impressive textures that do no justice to the otherwise amazing work done in character design and animations. Apart from those otherwise minor issues, Blackwood Crossingâ€™s main failure is its very nature.

So I think that for the story Blackwood Crossing wants to tell, and considering how obviously talented the development team is, as far as visuals and art direction is concerned, the video game medium, might not be the best one. Although I avoid the term â€œWalking Simulatorâ€, this case is probably the archetypical definition of it, the despairingly slow walking pace not doing any favorsâ€“ especially when it comes to backtracking back and forth for some of the simple puzzles. In other â€œgenreâ€ titles, roaming can be beneficial for storytelling, since the player, uses that otherwise dead time to think and digest storytelling, using the gameworld as a backdrop just like a movie uses slow takes and photography to let a viewer process the story, in the time between scenes. This process in Blackwood Crossing felt like a chore and was conducted just through the motions, instead of happening organically through game mechanics. The reasons were the painfully slow walking pace and the uninspired way that the player is involved, being restricted to either walk, inspect something, matching two characters into a dialogue between them or combining items in a very simplistic and linear way. 

Visually, although game areas are usually pretty small and congested, they manage to convey a dreamlike vibe, in some cases creepy even. Game characters are expertly designed and animated (some issues with lip syncing and Scarlettâ€™s reflection not moving the lips when talking).  And yet as a video game it is failed by the very mechanics that we are used to as movement â€œgameplayâ€. Combining the lack of meaningful gameplay and player involvement, I believe that maybe it would have been better for the particular creation and its story if it was told through a different medium such as a 3D animated movie or short.

65/100

Pros
â€¢	Highly artistic character models and game artwork
â€¢	Scarlett / Finnâ€™s performances 
â€¢	Some nice themes are examinedâ€¦.

Cons
â€¢	â€¦sadly there is not much time for the player to be immersed.
â€¢	30 fps lock and port technical problems
â€¢	Short even for genre standards
â€¢	Too simple puzzles 
â€¢	Fails to deliver any kind of gameplay, so as to give meaning to playerâ€™s interaction. The player could be not participating at all, and it would still have been the same story.


TLDR : Would recommend it on a huge discount for the amazing character design, animations and story. Not for the (lack of) gameplay.


Î•Î»Î»Î·Î½Î¹ÎºÎ® Î­ÎºÎ´Î¿ÏƒÎ· ÏƒÏ„Î¿ http://ragequit.gr/reviews/item/blackwood-crossing-pc-review

review:

Das Spiel selbst ist sehr einfach gehalten, hier und da mal knifflig, aber nichts woran man verzweifeln wird. Das setzt den Fokus selbst auf die Geschichte. Einige sagen, sie sei zu vorhersehbar, was ich nur verneinen kann. Man hat eine gewissen Ahnung, in welche Richtung diese Geschichte gehen kÃ¶nnte, doch Sicherheit gibt einen das Spiel nicht. Es kÃ¶nnte auch so, oder noch ganz anders sein. "Man weiÃŸ von Anfang an, was passieren wird" ist einfach zu sagen, wenn man die Geschichte kennt. Und selbst wenn tut das nichts zur Sache, weil die Geschichte wunderbar erzÃ¤hlt wird. Auch die Grafik ist meiner Meinung nach wunderschÃ¶n und fÃ¼gt sich passend der Geschichte an und der englsche Akzent passt zu Geschichte.
Einziger Kritikpunkt ist der Preis. Ich wÃ¼rde mir das Spiel wohl wieder holen, am Ende bei der Spieldauer, so schÃ¶n die Geschichte auch ist, aber ein mulmiges GefÃ¼hlt haben.

So. Yeah.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977655058', 'num_games_owned': 383, 'num_reviews': 158, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1494097884}
review:
Vor einigen Tagen habe ich dieses Spiel abgeschlossen, nachdem ich es von einer Freundin als Geschenk erhalten hatte. Danke dafÃ¼r noch einmal Sophie. :)

[h1]Was ist "Blackwood Crossing"?[/h1]
Es handelt sich hier um ein kleines Adventure, welches vor Allem durch seine Story, die ErzÃ¤hlung und die Neugier des Spielers lebt. Man selbst spielt die groÃŸe Schwester eines Geschwisterpaars und "rutscht" in eine mysteriÃ¶se ErzÃ¤hlung hinein. Das Spiel ist dabei streckenweise extrem dÃ¼ster und durchaus creepy, aber zwischendurch auch immer wieder mit einer Prise Witz und Humor versehen. Es gibt, anders als bei vielen anderen "Walking-Simulatoren", einige Gameplay- und RÃ¤tselelemente im Spiel die es zu meistern gilt. Nichts davon ist Ã¼berragend schwer, aber man muss hier und da durchaus die grauen Zellen anstrengen.

[h1]PrÃ¤sentation[/h1]
Im GroÃŸen und Ganzen handelt es sich um ein optisch bezauberndes und erzÃ¤hlerisch sehr gutes Spiel. Es gibt tolle Sprecher, die Grafik und der Sound passt stets super zum Geschehen. Wenn man eine bewegende und mysteriÃ¶se Story mit viel Tiefgang erleben mÃ¶chte, sollte man hier definitiv zugreifen. Die Entwickler haben eine Menge MÃ¼he in Details gesteckt die einen bezaubern wollen.

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Meiner Meinung nach eine klare Kaufempfehlung.


Nachfolgend noch eine kurze Pro- und Contra Ãœbersicht:

[u][b]Pro:[/b][/u]
- toller Grafikstil (sehr stimmig)
- tolle englische Sprecher
- stets passende musikalische Untermalung bzw. Soundkulissen
- teils sehr dÃ¼ster aber auch Humor und "frÃ¶hliche Momente" vorhanden
- tiefgrÃ¼ndige Geschichte die zum Nachdenken anregt
(- keine "Jumpscares")
- 30FPS Lock wurde durch einen Patch aufgehoben sodass nun mit 60FPS gespielt werden kann

[u][b]Contra:[/b][/u]
- kurze Spielzeit (ca. 2-3 Stunden) -> diese aber hervorragend ausgefÃ¼llt
- kleine Soundbugs bei der Sprachausgabe

author: {'steamid': '76561198002489638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1492636072}
review: I really want to like this game. The story is told in a very sensitive and emotional way, but at the same it follows that one path, which it doesn't leave. I could live with the rather slow walking of the charakter and the so called "puzzles" but I couldn't shake the feeling, that there was so much more potential in this one. All in all, if you wan't to play this game, don't make the same mistake as I did: Don't set your expectations too high.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198037280622', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1492433335}
review:
A touching experience with beatuiful moments - and a lot to dislike, to be honest.
I almost gave a thumb DOWN, to be REALLY honest.
The logical and emotional ending actually won me over again - so, yeah, its a lot of walking and not that much of puzzling, but what is there can be a bit irritating at times. At one point, you are even expected to guess the correct window you can open - in the interior of a train where absolutely every window looks exactly the same - no hint or anything.
Just as an example of what you should expect.

Oh, and the other thing. Finn. He is annoying. As in R E A L L Y annoying. I started to downright hate his scenes in the game, where I really like all the other story parts - kinda backward considering his wellbeing should be your major motive to play this game. I started to hate his oversized head, his all-time-complaining, permanently offended rants and even his super hero cape with the F on it - dudes, I was really glad to be a single child.
I was about to ragequit as to the annoyance of that little ... nevermind.
Enjoyable after all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004296439', 'num_games_owned': 700, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1492840644}
review:
First a Warning: This is a port from PS4 and while I'm not sold that it is in particularly worse than any other port for PC, it is worth looking around for issues that people might be having with similar systems to yours.  My game ran perfectly; I didn't have any performance issues.  Now onto the review...
___________________

It has its problems... Let's get those out of the way first.

The movement speed of your character of your character, in general, is like walking with a double limp at times.  What happened to her hips?  Are we talking early onset osteoporosis? It's never revealed why your character can't move faster than a slightly inebriated sloth. This is the most critical mechanical issue the game has (I had no performance issues to speak of) but I didn't find myself complaining or finding it tedious aside from one portion of the game where a lot of different objectives in a puzzle are further apart than at any other point of the game, I found myself yearning for a sprint function during this segment.

This sort of sluggishness spills into other areas of navigating the game as well.  When interacting with the environment you are often forced to wait before you can do so.  Anytime a character is talking you are rendered unable to do anything. Want to learn about the strange curiosities surrounding you at any given time in Blackwood Crossing?  Sorry, you will listen to your little brother prattle on in the background with filler dialog and you will LIKE IT. 

The other flaw?  Well, you will probably get around 2 hours of gameplay out of this game.  Is the $15.99 price tag worth that?  That's going to have to be something you decide based on preference and wallet.

Now onto the good stuff, and there is a lot here.  Blackwood Chronicles offers itself up as an adventure game, but is only so much an adventure title as something like Firewatch is.  This is a walking simulator with some simple puzzle elements that help drive forward the narrative.  

You find yourself in the shoes of Scarlett, a young girl thrust immediately into a situation that is clearly strange and not altogether worldly.  Is it a dream?  Is it an out of body experience?  As you chase your wily little brother through train cars that suddenly bloom with grass and trees, you immediately know what you're in for while simultaneously having no idea what is going on.  It's going to be a wild ride.

You'll make your way through these dreamscapes that are all beautifully rendered in a vibrant and colorfully stylized art style.  There's a sense of whimsy in the art of this game, even when it gets dark and eerie.  You meet strange ghostly individuals, all colorless except for paper mache masks they are adorned with.  As you interact with them, the puzzle becomes clear.  You get one line of dialog from each and you must match those sentences together, who is talking to whom?  Once you successfully match the right two people together they disappear and reappear elsewhere and you are told a story through these word-puzzles that further the strange plot along.  From train car, to train car, from treehouse to cave and back again, you are being pulled along this linear but beautifully told and voice acted story of equal parts joy and sorrow, both playful and ominous.

While there are dialog options that allow you to customize your responses to the story laid before you here and there, for the most part, you are certainly on rails.  But if you want to be told a story that you can see coming a mile away that still manages to hit you right in your soul by the end, I can't recommend Blackwood Crossing enough.

If you loved Firewatch or even The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, you might find a spot for Blackwood Crossing on your shelf.
_______________________

If you'd like to check out some of the cinematic gameplay with a little bit of commentary I have an ongoing playthrough going up on my channel.  It's probably worth checking out at least the first episode if you're having trouble wrapping your head around just what this game is without spoiling too much.  Here's the first episode which spans around the first 25ish minutes of the game: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=18AQXduULA8

author: {'steamid': '76561198020125851', 'num_games_owned': 15680, 'num_reviews': 840, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1492653508}
review:
[h1]Story Driven Adventure Game[/h1]
https://youtu.be/1CUKYqU1WPM
+ Visually the game looks amazing.  Very vibrant and detailed with a style that reminds me of animated movies. It's very enjoyable to explore and gaze at everything in each room.
+ Story is very interesting and a bit surreal.  You are essentially in some sort of dreamworld created from the psyche of your younger brother (Finn) who feels betrayed and abandoned after you (Scarlet) stopped paying attention to him as you grew older. 
+ The atmosphere of the game is mixed with great emotional moments, but at the same time feels so dark and creepy with strange animal masked people leading you to astray.
+ Great voice acting


- Some of the puzzles can be slightly annoying. [spoiler]For example, there's one part where you need to bring a lit newspaper to break a lock, and the flame randomly goes out about halfway through. It took me forever to figure out that the reason the flame goes out is because the small side window was "slightly" open. This makes absolutely no sense as a torch would not go out simply because a window was open.[/spoiler]
- I felt as if you go through the same areas (the train) too many times. After a while I felt a bit claustrophobic and just wanted to get off the train so I could explore someplace new.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065551217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1492210889}
review:
Eine Geschichte, die es Wert ist, erlebt zu werden

An sich ist es schwer dem Spiel eine wirkliche Storyline zu entnehmen, denn das Spiel erzÃ¤hlt keine linear ablaufende Geschichte. Vielmehr werden dem Spieler Ã¼ber mehrere kleine SchauplÃ¤tze hinweg Storyteile prÃ¤sentiert, die erst ganz zum Schluss ein groÃŸes Ganzes ergeben. Im Mittelpunkt des ErzÃ¤hlten stehen die Geschwister Finn und Scarlett, die eine scheinbar recht gut funktionierende Beziehung zueinander haben. Als Spieler steuern wir die groÃŸe Schwester und sind direkt in den ersten Minuten dem verspielten Wesen des kleinen Bruders, Finn, ausgesetzt, der uns auf einer Zugreise mehr oder weniger dazu zwingt mit ihm das Spiel â€œSimon saysâ€ zu spielen. Schnell wird einem als Spieler aber klar, dass nicht alles so einfach ist, wie es zu Beginn scheint und es in Blackwood Crossing um deutlich mehr geht, als ums Babysitten unseres kleinen Bruders. Im Spiel ist es eure Aufgabe als Scarlett festzustellen, was passiert ist und die Vergangenheit zu rekonstruieren. Die Details darÃ¼ber mÃ¶chte ich euch hier nun aber nicht vorwegnehmen.

Die Dialoge im Spiel sind Ã¼berzeugend und liebevoll geschrieben. Obwohl Geschichten Ã¼ber Liebe und Familie ein sehr groÃŸes Potential haben, lÃ¤cherlich zu werden, schaffen die Storyschreiber es immer den richtigen Ton zu treffen. An einigen Stellen kann man auch selbst wÃ¤hlen, ob Scarlett auf eine Situation herzlich, kalt oder sarkastisch reagieren soll. Das ist letztlich nicht entscheidend fÃ¼r die Geschichte, macht das Erlebnis aber doch ein StÃ¼ck weit immersiver.

Ich will nicht lÃ¼gen: wohin die Reise in Blackwood Crossing geht, werden die meisten Spieler â€“ zumindest im Groben â€“ schnell erahnen kÃ¶nnen. Dass das Spiel etwas besonderes ist, merkt man aber daran, dass auch das dem Erlebnis an sich keinen Abbruch tut.  So ist es am Ende nicht wirklich wichtig, was erzÃ¤hlt wird, sondern wie es erzÃ¤hlt wird und vor allem was fÃ¼r ein GefÃ¼hl das Spiel beim geneigten Spieler auslÃ¶st. Ich versuche es zu erklÃ¤ren: Kennt ihr das GefÃ¼hl, wenn ihr euch an einen schÃ¶nen Moment in eurer Vergangenheit erinnert â€“  Fahrradfahren mit alten Freunden, die ihr schon lange nicht mehr gesehen habt, ein Kuss mit eurer ersten groÃŸen Liebe, ein Spaziergang mit einem schon lange verstorbenen geliebten Menschen â€“ einen Moment, in dem alles in Ordnung war. Auch wenn ihr wisst, dass dieser Moment vergangen ist, so kÃ¶nnt ihr euch doch daran erfreuen, wie schÃ¶n dieser eine Moment war und ihr seid dankbar dafÃ¼r, ihn erlebt haben zu dÃ¼rfen, wobei dabei immer der Schmerz mitwirkt, dass das Vergangene nie wieder sein wird. Exakt dieses GefÃ¼hl schaffte es Blackwood Crossing nahezu konstant in mir zu erzeugen.

Beeindruckend ist weiterhin, wie die Entwickler einem das, was sie erzÃ¤hlen wollen, nicht einfach ins Gesicht klatschen, sondern alles auf mehreren Ebenen â€“ also nicht nur durch das gesprochene Wort, sondern auch durch das Design der Level oder die Ausgestaltung der Charaktere â€“ transportieren. So hat der Bully aus der Schule eine hÃ¤ssliche Fratze zum Gesicht, wÃ¤hrend Mutter und Vater der Kinder mit LÃ¶wenkÃ¶pfen dargestellt werden. Auch wenn es bereits einige Tage her ist, dass ich den Titel gespielt habe, fallen mir immer noch Details ein die â€“ wenn man sie richtig interpretiert â€“ die Story erweitern oder ergÃ¤nzen.

Blackwood Crossing verarbeitet sehr nachvollziehbar und einfÃ¼hlsam die Liebe, die man zu seinen NÃ¤chsten empfindet, deren Verlust und dessen Verarbeitung. Dabei verfallen die Schreiberlinge nie in oberflÃ¤chliches Gelaber, im Gegenteil. Von der ersten Minute an wird eine Verbindung zwischen den Charakteren und dem Spieler hergestellt, die im weiteren Verlauf sukzessive verstÃ¤rkt wird und nie aufgesetzt wirkt.

 

WunderschÃ¶ne musikalische Untermalung

Eine gute Story wirkt beim Spieler natÃ¼rlich nur halb so gut, wenn der Soundtrack nicht stimmt. Zum GlÃ¼ck hat Blackwood Crossing dieses Problem nicht, der Soundtrack ist nÃ¤mlich in nahezu jedem Moment perfekt abgemischt und steht Titeln wie Life is Strange oder Journey meiner Meinung nach in nichts nach. So treffen die Entwickler nicht nur immer den richtigen Ton zum richtigen Zeitpunkt, der Soundtrack ist auch vom Spiel losgelÃ¶st mal eine Empfehlung wert. Sehr gut gelingt dem Soundtrack vor allem der Wechsel von beruhigend, entspannenden Momenten hin zu spannenden, adrenalingeladenen Momenten und wieder zurÃ¼ck, was im Spiel doch einige Male passiert. Insgesamt eine perfekte musikalische Untermalung.

 

Ideenreiches und vielschichtiges Design

Ein ganz groÃŸes Lob haben sich die Entwickler auch fÃ¼r das Design verdient. Und damit meine ich nicht nur den reinen Stil des Spiels, der tatsÃ¤chlich hervorragend gelungen ist. Die gesamte Welt wirkt sehr authentisch. Angefangen bei den SchauplÃ¤tzen im Ganzen, die â€“ wenn sie nicht ein reiner Schlauch sind â€“ insgesamt immer recht klein gehalten sind, bis hin zu den kleinsten Details, wirkt hier nichts nur zufÃ¤llig platziert.
Wie ich oben bereits angeschnitten habe, nutzen die Entwickler an vielen Stellen auch das Leveldesign â€“ insbesondere die detailierte Einrichtung â€“ um das Storytelling voranzutreiben. Das alles hebt Blackwood Crossing letztlich auch designtechnisch vom reinen â€œ08/15-Walkingsimulatorâ€ ab. Das Spiel wird dadurch enorm vielschichtig und regt wÃ¤hrend dem durchlaufen der Story aber auch darÃ¼ber hinaus dazu an, sich tiefergehend mit dem Spiel auseinanderzusetzen.

Insgesamt wÃ¼rde ich hier wirklich gerne noch weiter ins Detail gehen, da aber leider jedes weitere Wort schon Gefahr lÃ¤uft, euch den SpaÃŸ am Spiel zu verderben, muss ich hier aufhÃ¶ren.

Nur mÃ¤ÃŸige InteraktivitÃ¤t, aber dafÃ¼r auf den Punkt, wenn nÃ¶tig

Wie fÃ¼r einen sogenannten â€Walking Simulatorâ€œ Ã¼blich, braucht ihr auch hier keinen Oberhammer zu erwarten. Den absoluten GroÃŸteil der knapp 2 1/2 Std Spielzeit verbringt ihr damit, ohne grÃ¶ÃŸere InteraktionsmÃ¶glichkeiten, euch mit der Story auseinanderzusetzen.  Der andere Teil des Spiels besteht im LÃ¶sen von recht anspruchslosen RÃ¤tseln. Euch werden kleine GesprÃ¤chsfetzen diverser Charaktere vorgegeben, welche ihr in die richtige Reihenfolge bringen mÃ¼sst. Das ist nicht wirklich schwer, es hilft aber sehr, sich intensiver mit dem ErzÃ¤hlten auseinander zu setzen. Denn in den Pausen, in denen man Ã¼berlegt, wer was zu wem gesagt haben kÃ¶nnte, kann das GehÃ¶rte verabeitet werden und sich festsetzen. Alles in Allem geht es fÃ¼r Spiele dieses Genres hier ohnehin um den goldenen Blumentopf. Die Entwickler geben einem zu keinem Zeitpunkt Ã¼berflÃ¼ssiges herumgeklicke, sondern bauen das RÃ¤tsellÃ¶sen flÃ¼ssig in den Verlauf des Spiels ein. Lediglich an einer Stelle, ist die LÃ¶sung eines Puzzles mit Backtracking verbunden, das macht die Erfahrung letztlich aber auch nicht kaputt. Das Gameplay steht der Story nicht stÃ¶rend im Weg und ist unterhaltsam, wo es vorkommt. Alles in allem ist das fÃ¼r Spiele dieses Genres positiv zu werten.


Story - 8.5
Soundtrack - 10
Design - 10
InteraktivitÃ¤t - 8

Endwertung: 9.1

Fazit: Wer Spiele wie Life is Strange oder Gone Home mochte, wird sich auch in diesen Titel mit viel SpaÃŸ und groÃŸen Emotionen verlieben kÃ¶nnen. Aber auch, wer bisher noch kein groÃŸer Fan des Genres ist, kÃ¶nnte hier den perfekten Einstieg finden. Blackwood Crossing ist insgesamt ein wunderschÃ¶nes Spiel, mit einer packend erzÃ¤hlten Geschichte und einem Soundtrack, der die ErzÃ¤hlung perfekt unterstÃ¼tzt. Es ist definitiv eine der besten Erfahrungen, die ich dieses Jahr im Videospielbereich machen werde und hat mir zum Schluss sogar ein paar TrÃ¤nen abjagen kÃ¶nnen.

Dieses Review finden sie auch unter: http://www.amazingnerds.de/2017/04/19/review-blackwood-crossing-emotionsbombe-an-der-indiefront/

author: {'steamid': '76561198333346351', 'num_games_owned': 243, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1513925513}
review: This game is absolutely beautiful - the artwork, the animation, the storyline...so much depth and such intrigue...You get drawn into it very quickly, and it's hard to get out, and when it ends you just wish there was more. Luckily you can replay and try new things, although I admit I've only played through once so I can't speak for it's replayability. Some of the mechanics and graphics may seem simple to some people, depending on what games you're used to playing, but it's the entire package that makes Blackwood Crossing such a masterpiece. It's WELL worth the money, and you'll love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995633713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1493097575}
review:
**Edit: I was able to get the game working with out any issues with frames, the motion is still a bit laggy and feels like walking through syrup. The storytelling was well done, puzzels are straight forward. The game is short but worth playing, finished the whole thing in less than 3 hours. Changed to recommended after completing the game. Original review is below.

I want to like this game. Hell, I want to play this game, but I can't get more than 5min in. The framerate is absolute unplayable skippy garbage. I'm running a rig with an i7-6700k 4GHz processor, 32gigs of ram and a GTX 1070 and am getting maybe 12 frames a second when it is consistant but other places where the game and camera freeze and then skip to where it should be. 
I really hope that PaperSeven patch this to make it playable on PC but as of right now don't pick it up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979084213', 'num_games_owned': 4500, 'num_reviews': 1010, 'playtime_forever': 158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1494155782}
review:
[b]Updated: May 7th 2017[/b]

[h1]Post-patch impressions:[/h1]

I'm happy to inform you that the recently released patch unlocks the framerate and let me tell you; it makes such a big difference. It makes a tolerable game wonderful in fact. I'm not sure why they haven't done this in the first place but I can only assume the PC version was an afterthought. Not anymore it isn't; it's the best version of the game out there. If you love short, story-focused adventure games look no further and give this lovely game a try.



Pre-patch review (for those interested why it was changed from negative to positive):

Some of you guys may know me from my other reviews. While I don't write all that often anymore I just wanted to talk about this game for a little while. Because what's there is great - really - but as a PC gamer I just can't recommend this and I came here to warn you. First of all, let me tell you that this is a really beautiful story which I will not spoil since it's only 2 hours long or so and you can easily finish it in an evening. The artstyle is also very well done.
But what saddens and pains me, though, is the fact that the performance of this game is absolutely horrendous. It's locked to 30FPS, there are hardly any settings and it very, very frequently dips below the 30FPS; I've seen it dip to 16FPS every few minutes (this is with a GTX1080). That, and movement also feels very sluggish. The game doesn't feel fluent at all. Therefore I can not recommend this game. Let the developer fix things before you give this a try. To be honest I don't expect them to fix anything, but who knows? As a game it's recommended, but as a complete product and with a pricetag this steep it's absolutely not recommended at all. You've been warned.

author: {'steamid': '76561198313422894', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 195, 'playtime_forever': 175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1492023067}
review:
[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33163055-HeikarGaming/]Folge meinem Kuratoren Profil [b]HeikarGaming[/b] fÃ¼r weitere ehrliche Reviews[/URL][/quote]

Anfangs war das Spiel etwas nun sagen wir gewÃ¶hnungsbedÃ¼rftig.
Doch wenn man sich auf das Spiel einlÃ¤sst wird es richtig interessant.

Blackwood Crossing handelt von einen sehr emotionalen Abenteuers zwei Waisenkindern mit toll gewÃ¤hlten Soundtrack und liebevollen grafischen Details.

Zum Schluss wurde ich selbst auch noch ein wenig emotional, was ich wirklich schÃ¶n fand.

PRO:
+ gute Grafik
+ tolle AtmosphÃ¤re
+ spitzen Soundtrack
+ positive kurze Story (fÃ¼r mich war die LÃ¤nge ausreichend)

CONTRA:
- Performanceoptimierung. Liebe Entwickler, bitte bitte schaut euch das nochmal an. Das Spiel spielt sich leider trotz spitzen Rechner schwammig und die Maussteuerung lagt leider auch. Bekomme zwar lt Steam konstant 72 fps zusammen, aber es fÃ¼hlte sich leider nicht so an. Besonders wenn man das Spiel zusÃ¤tzlich streamt merkt man es am anderen Ende, so dass das Bild gegen Ende auch ab und an hÃ¤ngen blieb.

Trotz der Performance Kinderkrankheiten ist das Spiel aus meiner Sicht eine sehr gute Emotion. Wer also mal was anderes spielen will und sich auf ein emotionales, atmosphÃ¤risches Abenteuer einlassen mÃ¶chte sollte zuschlagen!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993281646', 'num_games_owned': 529, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1491773664}
review:
I'll start with the negative point first:
- The slow walking speed drove me nuts evertime I had to go a few extra steps because I couldn't figure something out in the first try (I hate slow walking in games, even if it fits to the overall feeling of the game, like in this one).

On to the positives:
+ incredible strange, creepy atmosphere that makes you wonder what the hell is going on
+ superb art style
+ great music that fits perfectly with the storytelling
+ a story that slowly builds up and delivers with an emotional (though not fully surprising) ending

It's one of only two games that got me in a deeply emotional state and made me reflect on real life events.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979747533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1491664260}
review:
[h1]Blackwood Crossing[/h1]

[b]Ein kurzes aber intensives 1st-Person Indie-Adventure[/b]

+ stimmungsvolle Grafik
+ toller Soundtrack
+ gute englischsprachige Vertonung (deutsche Untertitel vorhanden)
+ bewegende Story
- unrunde Technik, ruckelt stellenweise selbst bei weit Ã¼ber 60 FPS
- Preis fÃ¼r die kurze Spielzeit und das schwache Gameplay zu hoch

Blackwood Crossing erzÃ¤hlt eine emotionsgeladene, intensive Kurzgeschichte.
Fans von Spielen wie "To the Moon", "Gone Home" oder "Life is strange" sollten auf jeden Fall einen Blick riskieren.
Den Preis von 15,99 â‚¬ finde ich jedoch ein wenig zu hoch angesetzt, eventuell auf einen Sale warten.

Die Story ist ziemlich gut umgesetzt, man spielt die Waise Scarlett, ein MÃ¤dchen im Teenageralter, welches sich anfangs auf einer Zugfahrt mit ihrem Bruder Finn befindet. Bald findet man heraus, daÃŸ nichts ist, wie es scheint.

Leider sind die Gameplaymechaniken wenig fordernd, RÃ¤tsel viel zu schnell gelÃ¶st und die technische Seite wirkt, trotz stimmungsvoller Grafik und sehr schÃ¶nem Soundtrack, etwas unrund.

Hab das Game trotzdem geniessen kÃ¶nnen und kann es durchaus empfehlen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076286805', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1491584892}
review:
A beautiful game that i couldnt stop playing when i started. 
- Its about Scarlet and her brother finn on their journey to freedom i guess you could say :) 
   You get really attached to those two... 
   Higly recommend to play it all in one go since it will all make more sense and be way more touching.

PROS:
- Great story, its beautiful, well planed and mystic.
- Nice graphics, They have a really "calm" effect and give you a nastolgic feeling of cartoons and a childs mind which is       good since its about too kids :)
- Nice puzzles that are pretty simple but still adds a lot to the story and they are done in a pretty cleaver way!
- A lot of Feels that goes up and down xD
Cons:
- the story is a bit short, really wanted it to be longer since i didnt want it too end! 
(- some character movment could be approved but its like yea nothing to care about really xD)

It was defently worth the money!

author: {'steamid': '76561198119374953', 'num_games_owned': 617, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1500811998}
review:
[h1]GefÃ¼hlvoll und aufregend![/h1]

Blackwood Crossing ist ein Indie Abenteuer Spiel mit einer faszinierende und emotionale Geschichte, die die zerbrechliche Beziehung zwischen verwaisten Geschwistern, Scarlett und Finn erforscht. Wenn ihre Wege mit einer geheimnisvollen Gestalt kreuzen, entwickelt sich eine gewÃ¶hnliche Zugfahrt zu einer magischen Geschichte des Lebens, der Liebe und des Verlustes.
VerÃ¶ffentlicht wurde es am 5.April.2017 vom Entwickler PaperSeven.

Die Geschichte sorgt fÃ¼r eine reiche, nachdenkliche und oft dunkle AtmosphÃ¤re. Wenn man emotionale, geschichtegetriebene Abenteuer liebt, dann ist Blackwood Crossing genau das richtig!
Und selbst das es "Kurz" ist, bedeutet das nicht, dass das Spiel schlecht ist, im Gegenteil! 
[i]Ich habe es in 2h 30min durchgespielt.[/i]
Die KÃ¼rze gibt einem oft diese "ich bin kurz vor dem heulen" und "WTF" wechsel sehr schnell was ich aber alles andere als  schlecht fand.

Der Soundtrack ist sehr schÃ¶n gemacht, da hat sich jemand wirklich mÃ¼he gegeben! Die AtmosphÃ¤re hat man passend zu den bestimmten Momenten gut hinbekommen.
Im Verlauf des Spiels kann man schon viele Vermutungen anstellen wie es wohl aus gehen wird, [spoiler] grade mit dem Wort "Umbra", das im lateinischen Schatten eines Verstorbenen, Geist, Gespenst bedeutet.[/spoiler]

[u]Meine Meinung:[/u]
Ich habe lange auf die VerÃ¶ffentlichung dieses Spiels gewartet und bin nicht entÃ¤uscht worden.
Selbst die "lÃ¤nge" fand ich fÃ¼r diese Art von Spiel und die Geschichte super! 
Das Spiel hat eine wundervolle Grafik was die AtmosphÃ¤re nur noch besser macht!
Und ich kann gestehen, ich habe am Ende doch ein paar TrÃ¤nen verdrÃ¼ckt. 


[u]Nochmal kurz:[/u]
Wundervolle und tiefgrÃ¼ndige Geschichte, ein wenig (gut) seltsam und gruselig, bezaubernde Grafik und Charaktere, einfache Steuerung, einfach schÃ¶n zu spielen. Ich kann es sehr empfehlen!
Selbst fÃ¼r die jenigen, die noch nie emotionale Spiele gespielt haben, probiert es aus! 

Hier findet ihr die Homepage: http://www.blackwoodcrossing.com/about/
Und falls euch der Stream bzw. das Lets-Play dazu interessiert: https://www.twitch.tv/videos/133862237

author: {'steamid': '76561197997089654', 'num_games_owned': 658, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1491443864}
review:
"Sometimes we push people away without meaning to."

Have you ever regretted the choices and events in your life that caused a distance between you and a loved one at some point, imagining how you could go back to fix it all in your head? That's the premise of Blackwood Crossing, a surreal firstperson adventure game about rekindling a neglected sibling relationship. If you're a fan of games like Alice Madness Returns, Papo and Yo, and Brothers, this two and a half hour game should be right up your emotional alley. 

You play as Scarlett, the older sister of Finn. You start off on a train which is the most recurring location as it gets transformed and twisted in surreal fashion to become a forest and then end up on Finnland ("there already is a Finland"; "mine's better"). You two seem to live with your grandparents, your parents being slightly out of the picture. Finn can't remember what his parents looked like, especially his mom's face. A schoolteacher, a schoolboy, grandparents, and a rabbit boy are other side characters who are all wearing masquerade-like masks that figure into this wider narrative to culminate in an emotionally rousing finale. There's a few twists that put the narrative all into perspective in a satisfying but also melancholic ending, which made me well up at points. 

Like in Groundhog Day, you're trying to fix all these events in your life that were mistakes that led to your drifting apart. You're older now and hang out more with your boyfriend, Cameron, and generally don't have the time to play with Finn. At one point, you're remembering this exchange where you're heading off to go out on a date but Finn wants to play with you in the treehouse making makeshift flying butterflies. This understandably creates a sense of abandonment, neglect, and anger in Finn. So this time, you're drawing the butterflies, cutting them up with scissors, and taping safety pins that work as a winding up tool, then using magic to give them life to fly like Finn does. However, Finn then remembers the bad memory of you actually leaving to hang out with Cameron and the butterflies that you were giving life to a minute ago turn out to be crumpled and limping on the table. 

In this game about memories, there are puzzles that fill in the blanks. The most recurring one is about deciding the order of sentences between multiple pairs of characters. Another one is saying out the events of a dragon battle in the right order through the phrases of their made-up language. Drawing out amorphous masses of darkness and bringing them to light or fire. Or collecting cardboard toy-like representations of missing parts to structures in Finnland and giving them life. None of them are too mentally taxing, although there was just one point I got stuck on trying to get a fire extinguisher out of its case that had been shut by a Finn Co. padlock made out of paper. 

For such an emotional narrrative game, it needs to be backed up by the presentation and boy does the game deliver on this front. I especially love the firstperson acting where you can see your limbs at all times because it gives a personal connection of you to the protagonist. In this case it's the proudly freckled redhead female protagonist Scarlett who wears black nail polish and Converse-like sneakers. There are some lovely animations like when you're holding a fireball in your hand, and you're given manual control such as when you ascend/descend a ladder, controlling the movement speed of each limb. You can see your real-time reflection in mirrors, which I did quite a bit against the train windows whenever I was holding up something. It's impressive work for an indie firstperson game, coming off the heels of Virginia and Firewatch. There is a beautiful score by Lowrider Sound that gives the game its playful and nostalgic flavour, closed out by a memorable ending song "The Crossing" (Ben Ottewell). The writing by Olver Reid-Smith is on-point in having well-developed sibling characters that never get too irritating and never feeling like the game gives too much exposition as to what happened, instead relying more on visual storytelling. Rosie Jones and Kit Connors do a great job in the voice acting of these British siblings as Scarlett and Finn, respectively. I first came across this game at EGX Rezzed only a week ago and was immediately struck by the very expressive and colourfully cartoony artstyle for a firstperson game, so I have to give thanks to Ryan Guy (art director), Matt Aldrige (character artist), Ben Mowson (environment artist), Iain Haskell (animator), and the rest of the team. Well done, PaperSeven (Brighton-based ex-Black Rock developers) in making such a memorable experience and what's bound to be one of my favourite games of the year 2017.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106029335', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1491464648}
review:
I -- wow, where to even start? This game hit [i] very [/i] hard in the emotional sense, and it's delivery was incredibly well done. The art style of the game is beautiful yet not extravagant, and the voice acting was amazing -- the delivery of many of the lines, especially toward the end of the game, really added that extra punch to the emotional core of my being. The music is also [i] fantastic, [/i] used very effectively for scoring scenes and conveying mood changes. Although it may be a bit slow for some, [b] if you enjoy narrative-drive games I would absolutely recommend Blackwood Crossing. [/b] Honestly, this is a game that put me in a truly emotional state with its delivery, and I really appreciate the way that it was done.

Mechanics-wise I will admit that I had some issues with the game, particularly in the area of framerate and unnecessarily slow movement speed. I personally managed to deal with the slower framerate, though for some this may be a breaking point in deciding to buy the game; as for the movement, if it weren't for the amount of backtracking you have to do, it honestly wouldn't be the worst character movement speed I've seen in a game. The controls were well-mapped for using a controller, though I can't speak for the key bindings for keyboard and mouse.

[b] Overall, I do stand by my recommendation of the game. [/b] If you have $15.99 (or your regional equivalent), a few hours to spare, and a love for narrative-driven games with a nice art style, I would definitely say buy it as priced; if not, you might prefer to wait for the game to go on sale before buying it, though I still recommend giving it a play. Either way, just prepare yourself for a good helping of emotions.


[i] Edited 04/06 to clarify my final thoughts on whether the game is worth it, particularly for the price (as per a comment receieved) [/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561197970551976', 'num_games_owned': 387, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1491429567}
review:
I've just finished Blackwood Crossing, it took about two hours which is what I expected going by the price tag. Not too short or too long for a 'Gone Home' style first person interactive story. First off I'd like to thank PaperSeven for reducing me to an emotional mess towards the end of the game. 

You guys really know how to pack a punch with a superb creative story that gets you so invested in these two characters. I also enjoyed the artistic style with the character models and environments. Performance wise It would have been nice to experience the game in 60 frames but to be honest the games no worse for being capped at 30.  

For people curious about this title, if you enjoyed games such as Gone Home or the vanishing of Ethan carter, games that kick your ass on an emotional level. Treat yourself to this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091071598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1491401696}
review:
There are few aspects which are quite neat and nice. Major positive aspect - is the story itself

Pros:
-An interesting story overall
-All game is based on puzzle-style. Great side, that it makes you think in some cases. Negative side, that it doesn't give any clues, doesn't involve in the story and you need to sort of guess of what is going on. Perhaps it is part of mystery developers tried to create.
-Music and sound enviornment is perfect. I would say sounds perfectly translate the feeling matter of story to the player.
-Interacted characters through out the game keep the story intruiging and interesting, wanting you to continue the game play.

Cons:
-It is not optimised for PC. For those who prefer PC over consoles - it is not the right way to enjoy the story. However, if you enjoy playing on consoles, I doubt it will cause any inconvenience. I would still keep it as a negative point, since the game is in Steam - for PC players.
-The game is rather short. Took me almost 3 hours with real-life-interruptions now and then.
-There is lack of story involvement for the player. Perhaps again, it is a mystery developers tried to keep, but on the other hand, the game is rather linear and it doesn't allow to drown into the mystery. Instead, we just follow the events 1 by another.

Overall, it was a pleasant experience and I would recommend to have a go for those, who look for something extraordinary and unusual. The game might be a bit pricey for what it gives, but hey, it gives way more than same amount of money spent in a pub or coffee shop. Try it out!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993537005', 'num_games_owned': 916, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1491397907}
review:
[b][u]See written review below[/u][/b] or watch it here: https://youtu.be/8ROC6qe0BDI
[h1]THIS IS A MIXED/INFORMATIONAL REVIEW! TL;DR: SKIP TO CONCLUSION![/h1]

Blackwood Crossing is a short, first person, story driven adventure game. The story centers around two orphans, Scarlett and her little brother Finn, and the relationship between them. You play as Scarlett, and you have always been close with Finn, but as you mature and developed new interests, the relationship between the two of you has become distant. You wake up suddenly on a train ride with Finn, and the two of you embark on a magical journey as you explore love, life, and loss.

The gameplay requires you follow Finn and a mysterious figure, while solving some puzzles along the way. Sometimes you need to find items or use magic to move on, and other times you need to put together both parts of a conversation in the correct order to open up magical barriers. Using magic, and carrying fire in the palm of your hand is neat and all, but it was more or less: take the fire, walk somewhere else with it, and then put it down. I really wish they had let me do more with magic.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list][*]intriguing story, and the ending is fine
[*]environments look pretty, and characters look good
[*]the instrumentals are done well, and the music is very good
[*]the sound effects are fine, and voice acting is decent
[*]full controller support[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list][*]more backstory, and details about the characters would be really nice to have because you may be left wanting to know more
[*]max framerate is 30fps; performance seemed a little bit choppy at times (this game is ported to PC from the PS4)
[*](nitpick) slow character movement; it feels slower than necessary, and there is a good amount of back and forth doing the objectives
[*](nitpick) very short game without a reason to replay it (took me a bit over 2 hours, but it can be done in less than 2)
[*](nitpick) keybindings are not fully customizable (you can only choose between QWERTY or AZERTY preset controls)[/list]

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Blackwood Crossing is a very short game, and the game is a lot more slow paced, and less exciting than the Steam trailer made it look. I liked it, and I thought it was intriguing, but it also felt like it was lacking substance and depth as well. I think I could have enjoyed the story a lot more if there were more details, and more backstory about the characters. All in all, I feel indifferent about Blackwood Crossing.
